title: If George Washington saw the current state of the USA, what would he think? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America
Politics of the United States of America

response.answer_text: Interesting question…I’m no historian, but I’ll throw some thoughts: He’d be shocked at how large and economically successful we are. The idea that we’d control all this land probably would have seemed pretty unlikely to him in his time — The French, English, Spanish, and Native Americans tribes were all spread across the turf that is now strictly known as the USA. I’m sure he’d spend a long time learning about how that happened.He’d probably be surprised by how racially integrated we are — likely pleasantly so, from what little we can gather of his thoughts on slavery. He seems to have believed slaves deserved better, but was resigned to that being the natural order of things, and something he couldn’t afford to do anything about. Seeing Constitutional amendments related to that change would probably be a real eye-opener for him.On the other hand, the Civil War was everything he ever feared would happen, and he’d probably read about that as if it were a horror movie.He’d be appalled by all the partisan fighting, as that’s something he specifically wrote about in his farewell address. Federalists & Democratic-Republicans were causing infighting in Congress and his cabinet, and blasting each other in the press. I think he’d be disappointed to see that things didn’t change after his warning. In fact, they’re probably worse now than they have been since Hamilton & Jefferson were going at it in the country’s first newspapers.He’d be perplexed by how involved in world politics we are. Washington’s America wasn’t this big and influential. They had border disputes to handle, and were trying to avoid big issues with France & England, so it’s not like they were foreign to diplomacy and trade issues. But, the sort of things America does in the middle east were things he actively avoided getting us into back then. (Take for instance, the slave uprisings in the Caribbean that the South wanted us to send troops to defeat)He’d be really surprised we’re still using the same constitution, or that there weren’t a LOT more amendments to it. There were people — like Jefferson— who thought we should have a do-over on the Constitution every 10 years or so. Given Jefferson was running for President (and became VP) as Washington was exiting, I’m thinking he expected that to work out…of course, when you’re dealing with a country of this size, a do-over might be a tire fire to get ratified, so he’d probably understand why WE don’t do it now. But, the 1800s didn’t do it? That’d be a surprise.As to whether what we’re currently doing fits what he fought for, I think he fought for the right for us to do what we think is necessary. He wouldn’t expect us to run things exactly the way they did…as said before, they thought their constitution was for them, and some future generation would rework the whole thing if they saw drastic enough problems. He might be uncomfortable with America meddling in world affairs, but the idea of something like the UN even existing was foreign back then. All things considered, I think he’d be intrigued by it, but likely wouldn’t be comfortable with that level of influence being thrown around between sovereign nations. But, he’d also be the first to say that’s his opinion, and that he already placed his sword in the ground long ago.

He would be probably confused and wouldn’t know what to think On one hand the USA have the mightiest economy and army in the world, they are more influential than any other country in history and the living standard of an average American is much higher than a living standard of a rich person in 1700s. However Washington would surely disapprove the morals of current era. Washington may have been a liberal in 1700s but now he would be regarded as a paleoconservative at best. His views on equality between races and genders, role of Christianity in public life etc. were very different from the modern ones. If many people in the USA dislike someone like Ted Cruz what would they think about Washington?
